There's usually a futbol game or some Italian news broadcast playing. Without fail there will be these elderly Italian gentlemen playing a traditional card game in the corner. For a great cup of coffee made however you like and the atmosphere of an authentic Italian cafe, go to La Prima Espresso.

direct_prompt: He explained that I was the first member of my own support group. I couldn't believe it - the only one who had died accidentally in that moment. I sat down in a chair and tried to process this new information. The guide offered me some tea and sat down across from me, ready to listen. I began to tell my story - how I had slipped on a patch of ice and fallen down a flight of stairs, leading to my untimely death. I talked about the fear and confusion I felt in that moment, and how I wished I could go back and change what happened. The guide nodded sympathetically and offered me words of comfort. As we talked, I began to feel a sense of peace wash over me. Sharing my story with someone who understood was cathartic. I realized that even though I was alone in my support group, I was not alone in my experience. There were others out there who had gone through similar traumas and were able to support each other. I left the support group feeling lighter, knowing that I had someone to talk to whenever I needed. I thanked the guide for his help and made a promise to myself to help others who found themselves in similar situations. I walked out into the afterlife, ready to face whatever came my way, knowing that I was not alone. The support group had given me a sense of belonging and purpose, and I was grateful for that.
human_text: " You have got to be fucking kidding me! " I couldnt believe it. My death was truly the first death of its kind. Sure, it was something special, but to be the first? For crying out loud. People dying from a dropping fridge? They had a group. Falling piano? Had a group. Choking on a chicken? They had groups for every fucking part of a chicking you can choke on. Wing group, leg group, breat group,... Getting killed by a falling quarter that was tossed off a building? They had a group. direct_prompt: This study investigates competitive nucleation and the Ostwald rule in a generalized Potts model with multiple metastable phases. By analyzing the nucleation behavior of various phases within the model, we aim to understand the conditions under which certain phases dominate the nucleation process. Our results indicate that the nucleation of different phases can compete with each other, leading to the formation of metastable phases that may persist for extended periods of time. Furthermore, we observe that the Ostwald rule, which states that the most stable phase will eventually dominate, may not always hold true in systems with multiple metastable phases. Overall, our findings provide valuable insights into the complex nucleation processes that govern the formation of metastable phases in multi-phase systems. We believe that our study contributes to a deeper understanding of nucleation dynamics in systems with multiple competing phases and could have implications for various fields, including materials science and condensed matter physics.
human_text: We introduce a simple nearest-neighbor spin model with multiple metastablephases, the number and decay pathways of which are explicitly controlled by theparameters of the system. With this model we can construct, for example, asystem which evolves through an arbitrarily long succession of metastablephases. We also construct systems in which different phases may nucleatecompetitively from a single initial phase. For such a system, we present ageneral method to extract from numerical simulations the individual nucleationrates of the nucleating phases. The results show that the Ostwald rule, whichpredicts which phase will nucleate, must be modified probabilistically when thenew phases are almost equally stable. Finally, we show that the nucleation rateof a phase depends, among other things, on the number of other phasesaccessible from it.

direct_prompt: St Paul's Cathedral is currently hosting a stunning large-scale video installation centered around the Virgin Mary. The installation, which fills the cathedral with images of the famous religious figure, is drawing attention from visitors and art enthusiasts alike. The vibrant colors and moving images bring a modern twist to the traditional religious iconography. This unique exhibit is a must-see for those visiting the historic cathedral in London. The video installation is sure to spark conversations and contemplation among those who experience it.
human_text: The piece has been created by artist Bill Viola as a companion piece to his Martyrs (Earth, Air, Fire, Water) work, unveiled at the London church in 2014.The video triptych features Mary with Christ on her knee in one scene, while another shows a woman breastfeeding.Viola has exhibited other "works for sacred spaces" at Durham Cathedral and Saint Mark's Basilica in Milan, Italy. "Mary is a universal female figure present in nearly all spiritual and religious traditions," said the US artist. "She is the personification of the feminine principle, related to ideas of creativity, procreation, inner strength, love and compassion. "The Reverend Canon Mark Oakley, chancellor of the cathedral, called the work "a contemporary contribution to a long tradition of reflection on the life and significance of Mary".The triptych, he continued, "encompasses the great themes of birth, relationship and death which is our shared experience of being human. "Mary can be seen, free of charge, in specially escorted timed sessions held between 11:30 and 14:15 on every day except Sunday.Follow us on Twitter @BBCNewsEnts, on Instagram, or if you have a story suggestion email entertainment.news@bbc.co.uk.

direct_prompt: Instead, God was a young woman with piercing blue eyes and a warm smile. She radiated a sense of peace and love that enveloped me in its embrace. I fell to my knees, tears streaming down my face as I felt her presence wash over me. "Do not be afraid, my child," she said, her voice like a gentle breeze. "I am here to show you the way." I was speechless, unable to comprehend the enormity of what was happening. God reached out a hand to me, guiding me to my feet. "Come, walk with me," she said, leading me down a path that seemed to materialize out of thin air. As we walked, she spoke to me of the universe, of the stars and the planets, of the intricate web of life that connected all living beings. I listened in rapt attention, hanging on her every word. It was as if she held the key to the universe in her hands, and she was sharing its secrets with me. We walked for what felt like hours, though time seemed to have no meaning in her presence. Eventually, we came to a clearing where a small fire burned brightly. God motioned for me to sit, and we watched the flames dance in the darkness. "Do you have any questions?" she asked, her eyes fixing on mine. I hesitated, unsure of where to begin. But then a question formed in my mind, one that I had always wondered about. "Why do bad things happen in the world?"
human_text: We are more powerful than he is, now. He tells me of how he got this way. Once, yes, he was capable of striking fear in those who worshipped him. He has love in his heart for all things, he tries to steer his followers to the right path. Francis will get a spot by his side in Heaven. The Lord is old. His creation was so grand, his biggest success. Now it' s polluted, dirty.

direct_prompt: This article presents a study on the high precision measurement of the coefficient of thermal expansion (CTE) of silicon carbide (SiC-100) for potential use in cryogenic space telescopes. The importance of accurately measuring the CTE of materials intended for use in space environments, especially at low temperatures, is highlighted. The motivation for this research stems from the need for reliable and stable materials in cryogenic space telescopes for precise astronomical observations. A detailed methodology is described for the experimental measurement of the CTE of SiC-100 using a specialized cryogenic setup. The results of the study show a high level of precision in the CTE measurement of SiC-100, with minimal uncertainty. The implications of these findings for the development of cryogenic space telescopes are discussed, emphasizing the potential benefits of using SiC-100 as a material with favorable thermal properties. The challenges and limitations of the measurement process are also addressed, providing insight into areas for future research and improvement. Overall, this research contributes to the advancement of materials science for space exploration, particularly in the design and construction of cryogenic space telescopes.
human_text: We present the results of high precision measurements of the thermalexpansion of the sintered SiC, SiC-100, intended for use in cryogenicspace-telescopes, in which minimization of thermal deformation of the mirror iscritical and precise information of the thermal expansion is needed for thetelescope design. The temperature range of the measurements extends from roomtemperature down to $\sim$ 10 K. Three samples, #1, #2, and #3 weremanufactured from blocks of SiC produced in different lots. The thermalexpansion of the samples was measured with a cryogenic dilatometer, consistingof a laser interferometer, a cryostat, and a mechanical cooler. The typicalthermal expansion curve is presented using the 8th order polynomial of thetemperature. For the three samples, the coefficients of thermal expansion(CTE), $\bar{\alpha}_{#1}$, $\bar{\alpha}_{#2}$, and $\bar{\alpha}_{#3}$ werederived for temperatures between 293 K and 10 K. The average and the dispersion(1 $\sigma$ rms) of these three CTEs are 0.816 and 0.002 ($\times 10^{-6}$/K),respectively. No significant difference was detected in the CTE of the threesamples from the different lots. Neither inhomogeneity nor anisotropy of theCTE was observed. Based on the obtained CTE dispersion, we performed anfinite-element-method (FEM) analysis of the thermal deformation of a 3.5 mdiameter cryogenic mirror made of six SiC-100 segments. It was shown that thepresent CTE measurement has a sufficient accuracy well enough for the design ofthe 3.5 m cryogenic infrared telescope mission, the Space Infrared telescopefor Cosmology and Astrophysics (SPICA).

direct_prompt: This paper explores the concept of maximum entropy from the perspective of the principle of virtual work. By considering the system as a whole and analyzing the work done by virtual displacements, a connection is made between entropy and the equilibrium state of a system. Through this framework, a deeper understanding of the relationship between maximum entropy and the principle of virtual work is gained. The implications of this perspective on statistical mechanics and thermodynamics are discussed, shedding light on the fundamental principles governing physical systems.
human_text: We propose an extension of the principle of virtual work of mechanics torandom dynamics of mechanical systems. The total virtual work of theinteracting forces and inertial forces on every particle of the system iscalculated by considering the motion of each particle. Then according to theprinciple of Lagrange-d'Alembert for dynamical equilibrium, the vanishingensemble average of the virtual work gives rise to the thermodynamicequilibrium state with maximization of thermodynamic entropy. This approachestablishes a close relationship between the maximum entropy approach forstatistical mechanics and a fundamental principle of mechanics, and constitutesan attempt to give the maximum entropy approach, considered by many as only aninference principle based on the subjectivity of probability and entropy, thestatus of fundamental physics law.

direct_prompt: In this study, we present NMR evidence for a strong modulation of the Bose-Einstein Condensate in the compound BaCuSi$_2$O$_6. Our nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) measurements reveal a distinct modulation of the condensate, indicating the presence of spatial inhomogeneities in the superfluid density. By analyzing the NMR spectra, we were able to determine the characteristic modulation wavevector and estimate the amplitude of the modulation. Our findings suggest that the modulation in BaCuSi$_2$O$_6$ plays a significant role in the behavior of the Bose-Einstein Condensate in this material. Overall, our results provide valuable insights into the nature of superfluidity in this compound.
human_text: We present a $^{63,65}$Cu and $^{29}$Si NMR study of the quasi-2D coupledspin 1/2 dimer compound BaCuSi$_2$O$_6$ in the magnetic field range 13-26 T andat temperatures as low as 50 mK. NMR data in the gapped phase reveal that below90 K different intra-dimer exchange couplings and different gaps($\Delta_{\rm{B}}/\Delta_{\rm{A}}$ = 1.16) exist in every second plane alongthe c-axis, in addition to a planar incommensurate (IC) modulation. $^{29}$Sispectra in the field induced magnetic ordered phase reveal that close to thequantum critical point at $H_{\rm{c1}}$ = 23.35 T the average boson density$\bar{n}$ of the Bose-Einstein condensate is strongly modulated along thec-axis with a density ratio for every second plane$\bar{n}_{\rm{A}}/\bar{n}_{\rm{B}} \simeq 5$. An IC modulation of the localdensity is also present in each plane. This adds new constraints for theunderstanding of the 2D value $\phi$ = 1 of the critical exponent describingthe phase boundary.

direct_prompt: He had heard stories of a powerful demon who could grant wishes to those who summoned it. With a mischievous glint in his eye, Oliver decided to summon the demon to do his homework for him. Late at night, when the moon was high in the sky and the stars twinkled brightly, Oliver snuck out of his house and made his way to the old oak tree at the edge of the forest. With trembling hands, Oliver drew a circle in the dirt and lit a small candle at its center. He recited the ancient words he had found in an old book, calling upon the demon to appear before him. Suddenly, a dark cloud formed in the sky, and a figure emerged from the shadows. The demon stood before Oliver, tall and imposing, with glowing red eyes and a wicked smile. Oliver's heart raced with fear and excitement as he made his request. "I summon you, demon," Oliver said, his voice quaking with nervousness. "I ask that you do my homework for me, so that I may be free to play and explore the world around me." The demon chuckled darkly, its voice like gravel scraping against stone. "Very well, child," it said. "I shall do as you ask. But be warned, all magic comes with a price." Oliver nodded eagerly, not fully understanding the consequences of his actions. The demon snapped its fingers, and in an instant, Oliver's homework was complete. The problems were solved with perfect accuracy, and the pages were neatly organized.
human_text: I would n' t get any of those answers from the flickering candle that sat on the floor, so I turned around to face the blithering sot that had summoned me this time. " Bartimaeus, " he said, eyes flickering back between me and the book he held in his hand. His knees were shivering. What kind of world was this, a world where seventeen-year olds had access to ancient spellbooks? Not that I should be questioning this. Apparently, Nathaniel had not been an exception. I turned into a hideous, five headed-dragon. Perhaps I could scare him out of the pentacle where he stood. No such luck. He barely batted an eye. Perhaps a shambling zombie? I shifted between several gruesome forms of undead before giving up. Teenagers these days. Desensitized to everything, I suppose. " Alright, alright. What do you want from me? " I grumbled. Maybe it would be just a quick errand. Oh, who was I kidding. He would probably keep me around as his slave for five years, maybe more - until the day I could outwit him. " Bartimaeus of Uruk, " he began again. " I command you to write a six page single-spaced essay on the cross-strait relations between China and Taiwan. " I became an ethereal puff of dark and foreboding gloom. I did n' t know what China was, or what a cross-strait relationship was, but I knew exactly what this *child* was asking of me. " Do you know who I am? " I thundered. "

direct_prompt: This article presents a theoretical framework for describing the flow of quark-gluon plasma (QGP) in 2+1 dimensions using causal dissipative hydrodynamics. The QGP, a state of matter with deconfined quarks and gluons, is expected to exhibit fluid-like behavior. The proposed framework incorporates dissipative effects such as viscosity and thermal conductivity, which may play a crucial role in determining the QGP's transport properties. By considering the system as a viscous fluid with thermal gradients, the model aims to provide a more comprehensive understanding of QGP dynamics. The framework's predictions could have implications for experimental observations of QGP in heavy-ion collisions at facilities such as the Large Hadron Collider. Overall, this work contributes to the ongoing efforts to characterize the properties of QGP and understand the fundamental interactions governing its behavior.
human_text: In 2nd order causal dissipative theory, space-time evolution of QGP fluid isstudied in 2+1 dimensions. Relaxation equations for shear stress tensors aresolved simultaneously with the energy-momentum conservation equations.Comparison of evolution of ideal and viscous QGP fluid, initialized under thesame conditions, e.g. same equilibration time, energy density and velocityprofile, indicate that in a viscous dynamics, energy density or temperature ofthe fluid evolve slowly, than in an ideal fluid. Cooling gets slower asviscosity increases. Transverse expansion also increases in a viscous dynamics.For the first time we have also studied elliptic flow of 'quarks' in causalviscous dynamics. It is shown that elliptic flow of quarks saturates due tonon-equilibrium correction to equilibrium distribution function, and can not bemimicked by an ideal hydrodynamics.

direct_prompt: The hypervolume indicator is a widely used metric for quantifying the quality of Pareto approximation sets in multi-objective optimization problems. Existing algorithms for calculating the hypervolume indicator can be computationally expensive and time-consuming. In this study, we propose a novel algorithm that efficiently computes the hypervolume indicator of Pareto approximation sets. The algorithm is based on the decomposition of the hypervolume into subvolumes, which are then aggregated to obtain the final hypervolume value. We demonstrate the effectiveness and efficiency of our algorithm through experiments on various benchmark problems. Our results show that the proposed algorithm outperforms existing methods in terms of computational complexity and accuracy in calculating the hypervolume indicator.
human_text: Hypervolume indicator is a commonly accepted quality measure for comparingPareto approximation set generated by multi-objective optimizers. The bestknown algorithm to calculate it for $n$ points in $d$-dimensional space has arun time of $O(n^{d/2})$ with special data structures. This paper presents arecursive, vertex-splitting algorithm for calculating the hypervolume indicatorof a set of $n$ non-comparable points in $d>2$ dimensions. It splits outmultiple child hyper-cuboids which can not be dominated by a splittingreference point. In special, the splitting reference point is carefully chosento minimize the number of points in the child hyper-cuboids. The complexityanalysis shows that the proposed algorithm achieves $O((\frac{d}{2})^n)$ timeand $O(dn^2)$ space complexity in the worst case.

direct_prompt: After years of delays and skyrocketing costs, work on the public building that ended up being £13m over budget has finally been completed, five years after its initial opening. Despite the challenges, officials are relieved that the building is finally finished and can be fully utilized by the community. The unexpected costs and delays have sparked criticism from taxpayers and government officials, who are calling for more accountability and oversight in future projects. The completion of the building marks a bittersweet moment for many involved, as the project's troubles have overshadowed its original purpose and potential. Moving forward, there will be increased scrutiny and regulations to prevent similar situations from occurring in the future. Despite the setbacks, there is hope that the newly completed building will serve its intended purpose and provide value to the community for years to come.
human_text: The Cube in Corby, which has cost £48m, now has its fourth floor office space completed and available for rent.The rest of the building includes Corby Borough Council offices, a library, theatre and register office.Tom Beattie, the council's Labour leader, said: "There was a cost over-run, but we held our hands up and accepted responsibility. "The Cube opened in November 2010, but it had issues, which included a leaking roof.Building inspectors said the helical staircase was "dangerous, like a helter skelter"  and it was described by the then Conservative opposition leader David Sims as a "poorly managed, waste of taxpayers' money".Work to bring it up to scratch has now been completed, the council said.Mr Beattie said: "We know it's taken a while, but we've got a building which is functional, people have got used to it and it makes a statement about Corby's ambition. "As you see the developments taking place around the town centre, I don't think any of that would have happened without this building being here - it's acted as a magnet to attract further business. "Rob McKellar, current Conservative opposition leader, said: "The Cube is a building Corby can be proud of and it represents Corby's ambitions. "It was controversial and there are multi-million pound overspends. "The public did punish the Labour administration at the ballot box in May and Labour has apologised, but now it's time to look to the future and Corby's is certainly a bright one.

The gear looked ancient, yet somehow still preserved after all this time. I couldn't help but feel a sense of unease as I stood there, surrounded by relics of the past on the surface of the moon. As I collected samples and took photographs of the artifacts, I couldn't shake the feeling that I was being watched. Was there someone else out there, monitoring my every move? Despite my unease, I knew I had a duty to my civilization to bring back these findings and unravel the mysteries of the past. As I prepared to return to my spacecraft, I couldn't help but wonder what other secrets the moon held, just waiting to be discovered.
human_text: [ translated ] It was the mystery of the century. Voyagers, looking for Spice, landed on the moon of a third planet from the star Proxell. What they found, no one could believe. Found on the surface was a white banner attached to the end of a fairly preserved metallic rod. Scientists have dated the material to be only approximately one thousand Creaxellion years old. Closer inspection of the banner leads some to believe that dyes were imbedded within the fabric, perhaps with the intention of inscribing a message on the banner. Additionally, small imprints on the lunar surface were also found; however, these prints did not match any life form found on Creaxellion. Aluminum pieces were found scattered within the flag' s viscidity, but scientists have yet to make anything of this. All of this was big news, considering there were no other signs of life in the entire solar system or any nearby systems... An examination of the host planet could suggest that a primitive civilization might have inhabited the planet and developed sufficiently enough to reach their satellite moon. However, there is a lack of evidence to support this claim. Other scientists suggest that the host planet, due to its lack of water and its high levels of radiation, could never support intelligent life. Whatever the case, the search for the truth continues, and our citizens continue to ponder our seemingly unbridgeable aloneness in the vast ocean of space and time.

direct_prompt: Proteins are essential components of all living organisms, performing a wide range of functions necessary for life. The intricate three-dimensional structures of proteins play a crucial role in determining their functions. One fascinating aspect of protein structure is the presence of intricate knots, where regions of the protein chain are threaded through one another. These knots are thought to play important roles in protein function, stability, and evolution. Understanding the formation and functions of protein knots can provide insights into the evolution of protein structures and their diverse functions. Studies have shown that protein knots can affect protein folding, stability, and catalytic activity. Furthermore, recent research has revealed that certain protein knots are conserved across different species, suggesting that they have been evolutionarily selected for their functional significance. Overall, unraveling the mysteries of protein knots offers new perspectives on protein structure-function relationships and the evolutionary history of proteins.
human_text: A number of recently discovered protein structures incorporate a ratherunexpected structural feature: a knot in the polypeptide backbone. These knotsare extremely rare, but their occurrence is likely connected to proteinfunction in as yet unexplored fashion. Our analysis of the complete ProteinData Bank reveals several new knots which, along with previously discoveredones, can shed light on such connections. In particular, we identify the mostcomplex knot discovered to date in human ubiquitin hydrolase, and suggest thatits entangled topology protects it against unfolding and degradation by theproteasome. Knots in proteins are typically preserved across species andsometimes even across kingdoms. However, we also identify a knot which onlyappears in some transcarbamylases while being absent in homologous proteins ofsimilar structure. The emergence of the knot is accompanied by a shift in theenzymatic function of the protein. We suggest that the simple insertion of ashort DNA fragment into the gene may suffice to turn an unknotted into aknotted structure in this protein.

direct_prompt: It started as a typical morning in America, with people going about their daily routines. Suddenly, a strange phenomenon occurred - everyone in the country simultaneously received a mysterious dose. Confusion quickly spread as people tried to make sense of what had happened. Some felt a sudden rush of energy, while others felt a sense of calm overwhelming them. The news channels were flooded with reports of the unprecedented event. Scientists scrambled to analyze the effects of the dose, but they were met with mixed results. Some reported feeling more creative and inspired, while others experienced strange side effects. The government issued warnings for people to remain calm and stay home until more information could be gathered. As the day went on, it became clear that the dose was having a profound impact on the population. Strangers became friends, enemies became allies, and the world seemed to be a more unified place. As the sun set on that fateful day, a sense of hope filled the hearts of Americans. human_text: Marry held the pills in her hand and looked intently at the clock. Everyone else in he room was too. Everyone in the country was, as far as they knew. And it was almost time. " Ten! " The crowd all said in unison, as noon approached. " Nine! Eight! Seven! Six! " Marry held the pill and her water close to her mouth. " Five! Four! Three! Two! One! " And then there was silence as everyone popped their pills and sipped their water. " Happy simultaneous medication day everyone " Marry told the room. Everyone nodded and began filtering out of the break room back to their jobs, confident the stigma of many medications had been eroded with their brave mass dosing. The next day Marry got pregnant. Unfortunately for her and many other woman on no other medications, the American Simultaneous Medication Time did n' t correspond with her usual birth control routine at all.

direct_prompt: In this study, we explore the concept of geometrically engineering the Standard Model by locally unfolding three families out of the E8 exceptional Lie group. By analyzing the structure of E8 and its relation to particle physics, we propose a novel method for mapping the dynamics of particle interactions onto a geometric framework. Our approach involves manipulating the geometry of E8 in a way that isolates three distinct families of particles, corresponding to the known generations in the Standard Model. Through this geometric engineering, we aim to provide a deeper understanding of the origins and relationships between the fundamental particles in the universe.
human_text: This paper extends and builds upon the results of an earlier paper, in whichwe described how to use the tools of geometrical engineering to deformgeometrically-engineered grand unified models into ones with lower symmetry.This top-down unfolding has the advantage that the relative positions ofsingularities giving rise to the many `low energy' matter fields are related byonly a few parameters which deform the geometry of the unified model. Andbecause the relative positions of singularities are necessary to compute thesuperpotential, for example, this is a framework in which the arbitrariness ofgeometrically engineered models can be greatly reduced. In our earlier paper, this picture was made concrete for the case ofdeforming the representations of an SU(5) model into their Standard Modelcontent. In this paper we continue that discussion to show how a geometricallyengineered 16 of SO(10) can be unfolded into the Standard Model, and how thethree families of the Standard Model uniquely emerge from the unfolding of asingle, isolated E8 singularity.

direct_prompt: Meet Graham, the new project by road safety experts and artists that aims to raise awareness about the vulnerability of the human body in car crashes. Graham has been designed with features such as a large skull, a flat face to protect his nose and ears, and extra thick skin to prevent against abrasions. According to his creators, Graham represents the perfect body that would have the best chance of surviving a car crash. The initiative hopes to prompt drivers and passengers to consider the importance of road safety and the need for improvements in vehicle design. Graham will be on display at various locations to educate the public about the importance of safe driving practices. His unique design serves as a stark reminder of the fragility of the human body in high-speed collisions. Road safety experts hope that Graham will encourage people to prioritize safety when on the road.
human_text: The incredibly lifelike sculpture was commissioned as part of an Australian road safety campaign.He has a head shaped like a boulder, feet snarled like tree roots and a chest like a wrinkled battering ram.Renowned artist Patricia Piccinini created the artwork, in collaboration with a leading trauma surgeon and a road crash investigation expert.The Transport Accident Commission (TAC) said he was designed to highlight human vulnerability on the road.Graham has a thick strong skull, a neck that melts into his torso and an inflatable chest that acts like airbags.He was made using silicone, glass fibre, resin and human hair. "I really listened and internalised the science of it and then I approached it in a creative way, on an emotional level," Ms Piccinini told the ABC. "The eyes are where the work is, it's where the viewer can really connect with him and empathise. "Joe Calafiore, the chief executive of TAC said that people "can survive running at full pace into a wall but when you're talking about collision involving vehicles, the speeds are faster, the forces are greater and the chances of survival are much slimmer". "Cars have evolved a lot faster than humans and Graham helps us understand why we need to improve every aspect of our roads system to protect ourselves from our own mistakes. "There's no secret behind Graham's name. It was a working title that stuck, according to the TAC, because he's just a normal Australian bloke.He can be viewed at the State Library of Victoria and viewed online.

direct_prompt: I was completely captivated by the story of a future society where telepathy is the norm, and murder becomes almost impossible to commit without being detected. The pacing of the novel was perfect, keeping me on the edge of my seat with each twist and turn of the plot. Bester's writing style was both engaging and thought-provoking, making me ponder the ethical implications of a world where thoughts are not private. The protagonist, Ben Reich, was a complex and compelling character whose descent into madness was both tragic and fascinating to witness. The supporting characters were equally well-developed, adding depth and richness to the story. The world-building in The Demolished Man was also top-notch, with Bester crafting a vivid and immersive futuristic setting. The novel's exploration of themes such as power, control, and the nature of humanity left a lasting impact on me, prompting me to reflect on my own beliefs and values. Overall, The Demolished Man is a true masterpiece of science fiction, and I am grateful to Quiet Storm for introducing me to this incredible book that I will cherish forever.
human_text: Imagine my joy: a cyberpunk fan, finding a tattered copy of some anonymous-looking book in some proto-hipster cafe (this was back before it was toooo hipster), and discovering the glories of Alfred Bester. (Seriously, The Demolished Man is good. ) It also fit in perfectly with the blue collar/gentrified charm of Pittsburgh in general, and the Hill District/Lawrenceville/Bloomfield in particular. nnAnyway. I have returned now in 2011 for a veg brunch, and it was a pleasant, if not-so-good-value-for-money experience. I got the True Grits (yeah, Jeff Bridges, yeah), which was a HUGE bowl of grits (some shaved, grocery store-feeling cheddar on top), a pile of delicious, chopped lemony kale, some pretty blah scrambled eggs and a large glass of cranberry juice (very healthy! ). Overall, it was fine. I didn't like the $12 price tag so much (seriously, grits is pioneer food and you're charging me $12! ), nor did I dig the shades of hipper-than-thou among the clientele, but shrug shrug.

direct_prompt: This study investigates the temporal evolution of step-edge fluctuations in a metal thin film under electromigration conditions. Using in-situ scanning tunneling microscopy, the authors track the morphology changes at the step edges over time. The results show that electromigration-induced surface diffusion leads to increased step-edge fluctuations as a function of time. The observed evolution of step edges is attributed to the mass transport of adatoms along the step edges. The study provides insights into the dynamic behavior of step edges under electromigration conditions, which is relevant for understanding the reliability of nanoscale electronic devices. Overall, these findings contribute to the fundamental understanding of electromigration effects on surface morphology evolution.
human_text: The temporal evolution of step-edge fluctuations under electromigrationconditions is analysed using a continuum Langevin model. If theelectromigration driving force acts in the step up/down direction, andstep-edge diffusion is the dominant mass-transport mechanism, we find thatsignificant deviations from the usual $t^{1/4}$ scaling of the terrace-widthcorrelation function occurs for a critical time $\tau$ which is dependent uponthe three energy scales in the problem: $k_{B}T$, the step stiffness, $\gamma$,and the bias associated with adatom hopping under the influence of anelectromigration force, $\pm \Delta U$. For ($t < \tau$), the correlationfunction evolves as a superposition of $t^{1/4}$ and $t^{3/4}$ power laws. For$t \ge \tau$ a closed form expression can be derived. This behavior isconfirmed by a Monte-Carlo simulation using a discrete model of the stepdynamics. It is proposed that the magnitude of the electromigration forceacting upon an atom at a step-edge can by estimated by a careful analysis ofthe statistical properties of step-edge fluctuations on the appropriatetime-scale.

direct_prompt: Snooker legend Ronnie O'Sullivan has once again showcased his dominance on the table, as he breezed past Boonyarit Keattikun in a stunning 6-0 victory at the UK Championship. The five-time champion needed just 56 minutes to secure his spot in the second round of the prestigious tournament. Keattikun, on the other hand, was left reeling from the defeat, unable to match O'Sullivan's speed and expertise. With his impressive display in the first round, O'Sullivan has set the bar high for himself as he continues his quest for another UK Championship title.
human_text: "I just try to play and enjoy it and see where it takes me," he said.Two more ex-champions, John Higgins and Shaun Murphy, also made it through at the York Barbican.Northern Ireland's Mark Allen also went through when he beat China's Chen Zhe 6-4.O'Sullivan echoed world number three Judd Trump's criticism of the early stages of the tournament, calling it a "weird set-up" with play on four tables simultaneously. "At the moment you've just got to look at it like a knockabout," the 40-year-old Englishman told BBC Sport. "With four tables it doesn't feel right. There's too much going on. "Two tables is the most you can do without it losing its class. You've got to have fun out there and not take it too seriously. "England's world number six Murphy, the 2008 winner, fought back from a 3-1 deficit to beat Brazil's Itaro Santos 6-3.But Northern Ireland Open champion Mark King lost 6-2 against fellow Englishman Sam Craigie after being docked a frame in bizarre circumstances.The 42-year-old - whose win in Belfast was the first ranking success of his 25-year career - forgot his cue following the interval and, after collecting it, was penalised for returning late to the arena.At 4-1 down King then scored a magnificent 141, the tournament's highest break so far, but world number 94 Craigie took the next two to get over the line.China's Liang Wenbo, the runner-up in 2015, lost a scrappy first frame against Australian Kurt Dunham but then showed majestic form, scoring two centuries and three breaks of 50 plus on his way to a 6-1 victory.Media playback is not supported on this deviceSign up to My Sport to follow snooker news and reports on the BBC app.

human_text: We didn't eat anything so I can't comment on the food. nnMy husband and I went to Buffalo Blues last night. We stood at the empty hostess stand for a while. When no one came to seat us, and we couldn't find anyone to seat us, we seated ourselves figuring that's what we were supposed to do. nnThe bar was full, but not packed. There were only two other tables with guests, one of which had empty plates on the table during this entire experience. After what seemed like forever, my husband got up to find a server. He literally walked around the restaurant to find someone, but couldn't. He then tried to ask the bartender, but she was just as elusive. When he finally found a server,  she acted totally shocked that we were there. Maybe if someone had been doing their job, they wouldn't be surprised to find hungry people in a restaurant. nnShe came to our table, got our drinks (a soda and a water) and asked us if we were ready to order. When we said no she said she would be back. We could see her chit chatting with another server, but again, couldn't get her attention to come back to take our order. human_text: " May, what is this? " You ask, as you stand back from the amazing skeleton of a creature hanging from above you. May, your personal AI assistant, hums as she browses her database. direct_prompt: This article presents a detailed analysis of the azimuthal structure of nuclear collisions. We investigate the distribution of particle production as a function of azimuthal angle in high-energy nuclear collisions. Our analysis reveals a preferential alignment of particles along certain azimuthal angles, indicating the presence of collective flow in the system. Through the study of azimuthal correlations, we provide insights into the dynamics of the collision process and the properties of the produced matter. These findings contribute to our understanding of the complex interplay between geometry, dynamics, and interactions in nuclear collisions.
human_text: We describe azimuth structure commonly associated with elliptic and directedflow in the context of 2D angular autocorrelations for the purpose of preciseseparation of so-called nonflow (mainly minijets) from flow. We extend theFourier-transform description of azimuth structure to include power spectra andautocorrelations related by the Wiener-Khintchine theorem. We analyze severalexamples of conventional flow analysis in that context and question therelevance of reaction plane estimation to flow analysis. We introduce the 2Dangular autocorrelation with examples from data analysis and describe asimulation exercise which demonstrates precise separation of flow and nonflowusing the 2D autocorrelation method. We show that an alternative correlationmeasure based on Pearson's normalized covariance provides a more intuitivemeasure of azimuth structure.

Despite this setback, May remains positive and is determined to come back stronger than ever. The England team will have to regroup and find a way to fill the void left by one of their star players as they push through the remainder of the season.
human_text: May suffered a knee injury while playing for Gloucester in last month's Premiership draw with Harlequins.The 25-year-old England's first-choice left wing at the World Cup and has won 19 international caps so far, but will now miss the Six Nations. "Following an operation on his left knee on Tuesday, Jonny May will be ruled out of the remainder of the campaign," said a club statement.Gloucester director of rugby David Humphreys described the injury as "significant" but refused to disclose exact details of what May had suffered. "He had surgery on Tuesday, the operation went well," Humphreys told BBC Radio Gloucestershire. "It's very difficult to put a timeline on any knee injury. It's a disappointing end to the 12 months for Jonny, both at club and international level. "May's absence is a further blow for new England head coach Eddie Jones, with Bath forward Dave Attwood and Leicester lock Ed Slater ruled out of next month's championship earlier this week.Northampton prop Kieran Brookes is also set for an extended spell on the sidelines after having an operation on his knee, as is Exeter centre Henry Slade and back row Dave Ewers.England start their Six Nations campaign under Jones against Scotland on 6 February.Anthony Watson and Jack Nowell featured in the World Cup and may be the likely starters at Murrayfield, while Chris Ashton and Semesa Rokoduguni are pushing for places in the squad.Humphreys hopes to have May back for the start of next season, with the winger likely to also miss England's summer tour of Australia.
